Package micycle.peasygradients.utilities

Enum Interpolation

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<Interpolation>
      • micycle.peasygradients.utilities.Interpolation
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<Interpolation>
    public enum Interpolation
extends Enum<Interpolation>
    Interpolation functions affect the interpolation factor (0.0...1.0) between any 2 color stops and therefore the appearance (ramp) of a gradient.

    For example, in linear mode, a point mid-way between two control points will use 50% of the left and 50% of the right; in exponential interpolation, the same point be an average of x% of left color and y% of right color.

    Author:
    micycle1

      Exponential Impulse Great for triggering behaviours or making envelopes for music or animation, and for anything that grows fast and then slowly decays.
      EXPONENTIAL  
      GAIN1
      Remapping the unit interval into the unit interval by expanding the sides and compressing the center, and keeping 1/2 mapped to 1/2, that can be done with the gain() function.
      GAIN2
      As above, but with K = 3
      HEARTBEAT
      Takes in a number between 0 and 1, and returns a number somewhere between 0 and 1, leading to a bit of a 'beating heart' type of effect.
      IDENTITY
      Almost Unit Identity This is another near-identiy function, but this one maps the unit interval to itself.
      LINEAR
      No transformation; completely linear.
      PARABOLA  
      SINE  
      SMOOTH_STEP  
      SMOOTHER_STEP
      Ken Perlin's smoother step, a simoid like function.

    • Enum Constant Detail

      • LINEAR

        public static final Interpolation LINEAR
        No transformation; completely linear.

      • IDENTITY

        public static final Interpolation IDENTITY
        Almost Unit Identity This is another near-identiy function, but this one maps the unit interval to itself. But it is special in that not only remaps 0 to 0 and 1 to 1, but has a 0 derivative at the origin and a derivative of 1 at 1, making it ideal for transitioning things from being stationary to being in motion as if they had been in motion the whole time. https://www.iquilezles.org/www/articles/functions/functions.htm

      • SMOOTH_STEP

        public static final Interpolation SMOOTH_STEP

      • SMOOTHER_STEP

        public static final Interpolation SMOOTHER_STEP
        Ken Perlin's smoother step, a simoid like function.

      • EXPONENTIAL

        public static final Interpolation EXPONENTIAL

      • CUBIC

        public static final Interpolation CUBIC

      • BOUNCE

        public static final Interpolation BOUNCE
        Provides a reversible parabolic bouncing easing out function. From t=0 value starts with an accelerating motion until destination reached then it bounces back in increasingly small bounces finally settling at 1 when t=1. If the direction parameter is negative, the direction of the function is reversed. This can be useful for oscillating animations.

      • CIRCULAR

        public static final Interpolation CIRCULAR

      • SINE

        public static final Interpolation SINE

      • PARABOLA

        public static final Interpolation PARABOLA

      • GAIN1

        public static final Interpolation GAIN1
        Remapping the unit interval into the unit interval by expanding the sides and compressing the center, and keeping 1/2 mapped to 1/2, that can be done with the gain() function. K = 0.3

      • GAIN2

        public static final Interpolation GAIN2
        As above, but with K = 3

      • EXPIMPULSE

        public static final Interpolation EXPIMPULSE
        Exponential Impulse Great for triggering behaviours or making envelopes for music or animation, and for anything that grows fast and then slowly decays. Use k to control the stretching of the function. Its maximum, which is 1, happens at exactly x = 1/k.

      • HEARTBEAT

        public static final Interpolation HEARTBEAT
        Takes in a number between 0 and 1, and returns a number somewhere between 0 and 1, leading to a bit of a 'beating heart' type of effect. Sourced from https://observablehq.com/@mattdesl/heartbeat-function
